Fig. 1 Representation of MgO incorporation into CTFs. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRPD patterns of MgO@CTFs. Graph A: 10MgNO3@CTF (blue), 5MgNO3@CTF (orange), CTF (black). Graph B: 5MgAc@CTF (purple), 2.5MgAc@CTF (green), CTF (black). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 HAADF-STEM image of 5MgNO3@CTF (A) and corresponding EDX mapping images for nitrogen (B), carbon (C), oxygen (D), magnesium (E) and carbon and magnesium (F). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms (A) and CO2-TPD (B) of CTF (black profile) and 5MgAc@CTF (red profile). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Kinetic data of the propanolysis of NPA. Graph A: profile of employing 30 mg of 5MgAc@CTF (black), 10 mg of 5MgAc@CTF (red) and no catalyst (green). Graph B: profile of employing 30 mg of 5MgAc@CTF (black), 30 mg of MgO (orange), 30 mg of CTF (blue) and no catalyst (green). The lines represent the fitted curves based on the first-order nonlinear rate. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Kinetic data of the propanolysis of paraoxon-ethyl. Graph A: profile of employing 30 mg of 5MgAc@CTF (black), 10 mg of 5MgAc@CTF (blue) and 30 mg of CTF (green). Graph B: profile of employing 30 mg of 5MgAc@CTF (black), 30 mg of MgO (orange) and 30 mg of CTF (green). The lines serve as visual guides for ease of interpretation. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Top-view of the fully-relaxed CTF structure with an adsorbed propanol molecule (A). Side-view of the fully-relaxed CTF structure with an adsorbed propanol molecule (B). Top-view of the fully-relaxed CTF structure with an adsorbed paraoxon-ethyl molecule (C). Side-view of the fully-relaxed CTF structure with an adsorbed paraoxon-ethyl molecule (D). Adsorption energies and interaction distances were represented in (A) and (C). The fully-relaxed structure of the CTF presents a layer separation of 3.40 Å. Fig. 7 Scheme 1 Formation de 2-hexyl-2-decenal from octanal. The aldol intermediate was not detected. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 Propanolysis of 4-NPA, leading to propyl acetate and 4-nitrophenol as products. Scheme 2 Scheme 3 Propanolysis of paraoxon-ethyl, leading to diethyl propylphosphate and 4-nitrophenol as products. Scheme 3 Table 1 Textural and base properties of the synthesized materials. Chemistry, Federal University of Santa Catarina, 88040-900 Florianópolis, Santa Catarina, Brazil ⁎ Corresponding authors. Covalent triazine frameworks (CTFs) have emerged as robust materials with high thermal and chemical stability, tunable porosity, and significant potential for sustainable applications in catalysis, adsorption, and gas storage and separation. Recent advances have focused on enhancing their intrinsic basicity through the incorporation of alkali oxides, which, although effective, exhibit limited moisture stability. For many practical applications, developing strongly basic, water-tolerant CTFs remains a critical challenge. In this work, magnesium oxide-impregnated covalent triazine frameworks (MgO@CTFs) were successfully synthesized through a sequential process involving the wet impregnation of magnesium salts onto CTFs, followed by thermal decomposition. The synthesis procedure was optimized by investigating the best ratio of the metal salt precursor to support, as well as the type of metal precursor. Impregnation of MgO at 5 wt% provided the best compromise between enhanced basicity and retention of porosity. The materials were thoroughly characterized to confirm their structure, composition, and porosity. Their catalytic performance was evaluated in the production of 2-hexyl-2-decenal from octanal, achieving over 80 % conversion at 170 °C within 4 h, as well as in the propanolysis of 4-nitrophenylacetate (4-NPA) and paraoxon-ethyl. Remarkably, reaction rates improved by factors of 4.5 (4-NPA) and 300 (paraxon) compared to the respective spontaneous reaction. DTF studies indicate that the CTF framework interacts with propanol and paraoxon-ethyl, facilitating the interaction between the reactive species. This study presents an effective strategy to introduce stable basic sites into CTFs without compromising their porosity or stability, expanding their applicability in base-catalyzed reactions and other advanced applications. Graphical Abstract Keywords Covalent triazine frameworks (CTFs) Magnesium oxide Porous materials Transesterification Organophosphate degradation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The ongoing interest in materials with basic properties arises from their broad potential applications, including adsorption [1,2], CO2 capture and separation [3–7] and catalysis. Solid bases offer several advantages over their liquid counterparts, such as easier separation and reuse, improved safety, simpler handling and reduced waste generation. As a result, considerable efforts have been directed toward developing innovative basic catalysts for various reactions, including CO2 conversion into valuable chemicals [8–10], biodiesel production [11–13], PET methanolysis [14], and the synthesis of fine chemicals [15–18], among others [19–22]. The immobilization of basic species onto porous supports is a common strategy for developing recoverable base catalysts. This approach can also enhance the catalytic activity by increasing the number of accessible active sites and strengthening the intrinsic basicity. Commonly utilized porous materials used as supports for basic catalysis include zeolites [23–25], alumina [26], carbon [27–29], mesoporous silica [30–32], metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [33–35] and porous organic polymers (POPs) [36–38]. Among these, POPs are particularly attractive due to their highly controlled composition, adjustable chemical functionality, high surface area and tunable pore size, making them excellent candidates for catalytic applications [39]. Covalent triazine frameworks (CTFs) are a subclass of POPs known for their high porosity and crystallinity, typically formed through the trimerization reaction of nitriles under Lewis acidic conditions [40]. The classical synthesis method introduced by Kuhn et al. involves an ionothermal process in which monomers are heated with ZnCl2 at high temperatures (≥ 400°C) to form the framework [41]. This technique produces CTFs with exceptional thermal and chemical stability, making them highly suitable as catalytic supports for immobilizing metal complexes and anchoring nanoparticles [42]. Among the many applications of CTFs, their use in gas storage and separation, pollutant removal and catalysis stands out as promising routes toward sustainable processes [43]. In catalysis, increasing attention has been directed toward electrochemical and photocatalytic processes, particularly through the development of metal-free systems based on CTFs. Notable recent advances include the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CO [44], H2 evolution [45] and water oxidation to H2O2 [46], as well as photocatalytic synthesis of fine chemicals [47], hydrogen production [48], and oxidative reactions such as amine coupling [49]. The high density of accessible nitrogen atoms in CTFs yields basic properties to these materials, an important feature for both gas adsorption and base-catalyzed transformations. Consequently, CTFs have been investigated as basic catalysts in various reactions, especially for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides to produce cyclic carbonates [50–52]. Their basicity stems primarily from the nitrogen atoms within the triazine units and eventually from additional organic functional groups integrated into the framework [53]. Recent efforts have focused on incorporating strong basic sites into the structure of CTFs [54,55]. In particular, basic K2O sites have been introduced by impregnating CTFs with KNO3, followed by thermal decomposition to the alkali oxide. This modification significantly enhanced the basicity of the material without compromising the structural integrity of the support, enabling high efficiency in the oxidation of methylene compounds and the cleavage of lignin [54,55]. These advances motivate further exploration into the incorporation of other metal oxides into CTFs. The inclusion of MgO into porous supports has been widely studied, as it increases the density of basic surface sites and improves performance in adsorption and catalysis compared to conventionally prepared MgO [56–60]. MgO-based materials offer broad catalytic versatility, with recent applications including the dehydrogenation of alcohols [59], CO2 conversion to oxazolidinones [61], glucose isomerization to fructose [29,60], biodiesel production [62] and aldol condensations [63]. Moreover, MgO offers greater chemical stability than alkali oxides, enabling its use under a broader range of catalytic conditions and applications. In this study, we report a successful strategy for incorporating MgO into CTFs without significantly compromising the support’s porosity or structural integrity. The type of metal salt precursor and its ratio to the support were found to play a crucial role in ensuring the effective MgO dispersion. The approach significantly enhances CO2 adsorption capacity and catalytic performance in both aldol condensation of octanal and the transesterification of carbonyl and organophosphate esters. To date, the incorporation of water-stable, strongly basic sites into CTFs is yet to be demonstrated. Our results reveal that incorporating such basic centers not only improves the performance in base-catalyzed transformations but also opens new avenues for tailoring CTFs to diverse applications, including, for example, electro and photocatalysis. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthesis and characterization of materials The CTF employed as support for the basic sites was synthesized via an ionothermal approach, in which 1,4-dicyanobenzene was mixed with ZnCl2 and heated to 400 °C, yielding the CTF as a black powder. This method produces a material that is highly porous, crystalline, and thermally stable [41]. The XRPD pattern of the as-synthesized material confirms the expected long-range structural order of the CTF, with a peak at 2θ equal to 7.3°, corresponding to the (100) diffraction plane (Figure S1). Additionally, the broad peak at 26.1° corresponds to an interlayer distance of 3.4 Å between the stacked sheets. Additional evidence for the formation of the CTF can be found in the FTIR spectra (Figure S2), where the bands corresponding to the presence of the triazine ring are observed at 1510 and 1345 cm−1. Moreover, elemental analysis reveals that the experimental C/N ratio closely aligns with previously reported values for CTF (Table S2) [41]. Incorporation of magnesium oxide into the porous material was achieved by impregnation of magnesium salts followed by a calcination step, as schematized in Fig. 1. The complete procedure of the synthesis is described in the SI, as well as the detailed information regarding the amount of precursor added and metal oxide impregnated in the materials (Table S1). To the best of our knowledge, the incorporation of strong basic sites into CTFs has been reported only by Zhu et al., where K2O formation was achieved by impregnating CTF with KNO3, followed by calcination [54,55]. Here we reproduced the Zhu et al. methodology and further investigated the influence of the salt precursor, using potassium acetate as shown in Eq. (1). In addition, we explored the formation of MgO sites from Mg(NO3)2 and Mg(CH3COO)2 salts, as depicted in Eq. (2). (1) CTF + KN O 3 or K ( C H 3 COO ) → 400 ° C K 2 O@CTF (2) CTF + Mg ( N O 3 ) 2 or Mg ( C H 3 COO ) 2 → 400 ° C MgO@CTF The formation of the metal oxides can be identified by the XRPD analysis. Fig. 2 and S3 shows the XRPD patterns of MgO incorporated at CTFs (MgO@CTFs) at different ratios. When the wt% ratio between Mg(NO3)2 and CTF used in the impregnation step is close to 25:75, resulting in 10 wt% MgO (material labeled 10MgNO3@CTF), characteristic diffraction peaks at 42.9° and 62.2° are clearly observed, matching the (200) and (220) planes of the fcc structure of MgO [64]. Conversely, when lower amounts of precursor salts are used, leading to only 5 wt% MgO incorporation, the prominent sharp peaks of the oxide are no longer observed. This suggests that the MgO formed is homogeneously dispersed throughout the material, similarly to what was observed for the impregnation of MgO at mesoporous silica and carbonaceous materials [65,66]. On the other hand, when Mg(CH3COO)2 is employed the MgO peaks are visible even at 5 wt% loading. TEM analysis were conducted to assess morphology and obtain insights into elemental distribution. HRTEM images of MgO@CTF materials reveled layered structures that closely resemble the support (Figure S4). A combination of high-angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) imaging and energy dispersive X-Ray (EDX) was employed to investigate the distribution of MgO particles within the support. A HAADF-STEM image of the 5MgNO3@CTF material is presented in Fig. 3. The corresponding EDX mapping indicates that C and N are evenly distributed, consistent with the CTF composition. The Mg and O mappings clearly demonstrate the high dispersibility of MgO throughout the support, exhibiting an almost uniform distribution within the particle, which strongly correlates with the XRPD data. For 5MgAc@CTF, magnesium is also observed to be well dispersed within the material, though the presence of some nanoparticles is clearly evident (Figure S5). It is also important to mention that the chemical structure of the support material was not impacted by the metal oxide incorporation steps, as similar FTIR spectra were observed before and after the impregnation procedure (Figures S6-S8). Besides, no signal from precursor salts were observable. The thermal stability of MgO@CTFs materials also closely resembles that of the pure support (Figure S9-10). Two distinct mass loss events were observed in the TGA profiles: the first, corresponding to the desorption of adsorbed water up to 110 °C, while the second, related to the thermal degradation of the material, occurs between 580 and 800 °C. Notably, the TGA behavior remains consistent regardless of the type of magnesium salt or ratio used during the impregnation process. The XRPD patterns in Fig. 2 contrast with those of materials prepared with potassium salts, as shown in Figure S11. In the latter, intense diffraction peaks at 2θ of 28.2°, 40.3°, 50.2°, 66.3° and 73.6° characteristic for K2O were observed regardless of the potassium concentration or source explored in the impregnation step. This suggests the formation of large crystallites, as already observed in previous work [54]. The patterns also suggests that the formation of K2O is more difficult, since traces of precursor salts are observed, especially for KNO3. The specific surface area (SSA) and total pore volume (TPV) of the materials, measured by N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms, and the total basicity, evaluated by CO2-TPD, are shown in Table 1. As expected, the formation of K2O resulted in a large increase in basicity. However, this is accompanied by an expected decrease in the SSA and in the TPV (entries 1–4). Apparently, the best compromise between the increase in basicity and less impact on the textural properties is obtained when using potassium acetate for the material preparation. Similar conclusions are drawn for the MgO incorporation results. When high amounts of precursor salt were employed, pore obstruction and increment in the basicity were observed (Entry 5). Reducing the amount of salt impregnated is overall beneficial, especially when Mg(CH3COO)2 is used (Entries 6 and 7), with the lowest impact in the surface area (∼36 %) and increasing the basicity by a 7.3-fold factor ( Fig. 4). No apparent advantage is observed at 2.5 wt% MgO incorporation, as similar effects on porosity are observed with a lesser increase in basicity (Entries 8 and 9). Furthermore, computational models were employed to investigate the interaction between MgO nanoparticles and the CTF framework. Two models were constructed by positioning MgO particles with sizes of 4.0 Å and 6.0 Å at the entrance of the CTF pore. Upon structural optimization, the smaller 4.0 Å particles were found to enter into the pore, whereas the larger 6.0 Å particles remained at the pore entrance (Figure S32). These results indicate that CTF is an effective support for stabilizing smaller MgO nanoparticles within its porous architecture. When an excess of magnesium precursor is introduced, it is reasonable to expect that the pore capacity of CTF would be surpassed, leading to pore blockage and the subsequent formation of larger MgO particles on the external surface. It is important to note that the primary aim of this study is to estimate the maximum nanoparticle size capable of interacting with the internal pore environment of CTF. Therefore, detailed evaluations of adsorption energies and electronic structure are beyond the scope of this manuscript. The results observed so far let us infer the advantage of the MgO incorporation into CTFs over K2O. The CO2-TPD results reveal that comparable basicity arose from K2O and MgO incorporation, with the advantage from the latter regarding the porosity integrity. This may be associated with the more likely dispersibility of the MgO particles in the material as already discussed in the XRPD section. In addition, it is well known that K2O is prompted converted to hydroxide when exposed to water, resulting in base leaching and lack of recyclability of the material in certain reaction systems or conditions. Thus, catalytic activity experiments were further investigated with MgO@CTFs. 2.2 Preparation of 2-hexyl-2-decenal from octanal The activity of MgO@CTFs as basic catalysts was first evaluated in the conversion of octanal in 2-hexyl-2-decenal. The production of α–β unsaturated aldehydes is particularly attractive since they are classified as valuable intermediates in the production of plasticizers, lubricants, surfactants, biofuels and fine chemicals [67–69]. Moreover, aldol condensation serves as a benchmark to assess the catalytic power and stability of the material under conditions involving water formation at elevated reaction temperatures. MgO is well known for its high effectiveness in aldol condensation reactions. A computational study suggests that the conversion of acetaldehyde to 3-hydroxybutanal proceeds via a mechanism in which the carbonyl oxygen and α-hydrogen interact with Mg2+ and O2-, respectively, forming a six-membered ring between the aldehyde and the MgO atoms. This interaction elongates the bond length between the α-carbon and its hydrogen, promoting the enolate ion formation. The enolate then attacks the activated carbonyl group of a second molecule to form the C–C bond, yielding the aldol product after protonation of the alkoxide [70]. The aldol product usually is not isolated because it is prone to dehydration at elevated temperatures. For example, formation of 2-hexyl-2-decenal can be carried out from the homo-aldol condensation of octanal, followed by the dehydration of the aldol intermediate to the desired unsaturated compound ( Scheme 1) [71,72]. The reported high activity of mixed oxides in this reaction encouraged us to apply MgO@CTFs without addition of solvents [73]. Table 2 presents the activity of MgO@CTFs in the octanal conversion to 2-hexyl-2-decenal. In agreement with the literature [73,74], the aldol product 2-hexyl-3-hydroxydecanal was not detected in the reactions possibly due to the high reaction temperature employed which favors the formation of the α–β unsaturated aldehyde. Initially, reaction kinetics using 5MgAc@CTF were carried out, showing that optimal product conversion is reached after 4 h of reaction (Figure S33). Entries 1 and 2 indicate that around 5 wt% of MgO in the CTF is enough to achieve high conversion of the reagent to the desired product in the conditions explored. Entries 3 and 4 show that there is no positive outcome upon conducting the reaction under inert atmosphere nor employing a CTF with a higher MgO content in the conditions explored, respectively. On the other hand, when materials with around 2.5 wt% of MgO were used, lower conversions were observed (Entries 5 and 6), which could be slightly improved at higher catalyst to reagent ratio, as seen in Entry 7. For comparison purposes, the catalytic activity of a potassium oxide impregnated CTF was also investigated (Entry 8), reveling lower efficiency when compared to MgO@CTFs. This reduced performance may be attributed to the decomposition of the active site caused by hydration as a consequence from water generated as a side product. Notably, no dehydration agent was used in the reaction system, confirming that MgO@CTF remains catalytically active throughout the reaction despite water formation. As expected from the basicity determination, the pure CTF is not significantly active (compare Entries 9 and 10). The reaction system serves as a suitable platform for comparing the synthesized catalysts and identifying the optimal material, enabling a correlation between catalytic activity, porosity, and basicity. The catalysts containing 5 wt% MgO exhibits the highest TON along with relatively high product yields. Despite its slightly higher basicity, the 10 wt% MgO catalyst does not exhibit greater activity, likely due to reduced porosity. Conversely, the 2.5 wt% MgO catalyst shows a lower TON when the same amount of active material is used, suggesting that the slight improvement in porosity is insufficient to counterbalance the reduced basicity. Based on the aldol condensation experiments and material properties, we conclude that the best compromise between basicity and porosity is achieved at 5 wt% MgO impregnation. To evaluate the recyclability of the MgO@CTFs as catalysts in the 2-hexyl-2-decenal conversion, an experiment in the same conditions of Entry 1 from Table 2 was conducted. After 4 h of reaction, the supernatant was removed and analyzed whereas the reaction tube was recharged with octanal. In total 6 reaction cycles were performed, indicating that the material could be reused continuously with minimal loss in the catalytic efficiency (reduction of ∼14 % in the 5th cycle when compared to the 1st) without the need of catalyst activation (Figure S34). The persistence in the catalytic efficiency of the MgO@CTF material is remarkable specially when compared to the potassium oxide impregnated CTF recycle experiment, where the catalytic activity drastically falls to the spontaneous conversion in the first reuse (Figure S35). A plausible explanation for the sustained catalytic activity of 5MgAc@CTF, in contrast to the pronounced deactivation observed for 10KNO3@CTF, is the leaching of the basic oxide from the latter, triggered by water formation during the reaction. To investigate this hypothesis, water tolerance experiments were conducted for both materials (Table S5). Prior to the reaction, varying volumes of water were added to each catalyst followed by mixing for one minute. After water removal, the standard reaction procedure was conducted. Notably, even minimal water addition significantly affected the performance of 10KNO3@CTF. For this material, when an equimolar amount of water relative to octanal was introduced, the catalyst's activity is the same as for pure CTF, supporting the hypothesis that the accessible basic oxide had been leached. In contrast, the activity of 5MgAc@CTF remained unaffected even when exposed to three equivalents of water (relative to octanal), indicating a superior resistance to water-induced deactivation. To assess potential losses in catalytic efficiency of MgO@CTF, the material was characterized after being employed in the aldol condensation reaction. After use the catalyst was recovered, washed with hexane and acetone and dried at mild temperature (120 °C). As shown in Figure S36, the obstruction of pores, probably by organic residues, is evident. However, after reactivation at 400 °C, the N2 physisorption isotherm profile of the spent catalyst closely resembles that of the fresh material, with a reduction of about 29 % in the SSA. Furthermore, the magnesium content decreased approximately 7 % compared to the pristine sample (Table S6), indicating limited metal loss. These results suggest that the observed decline in catalytic activity is likely due to partial pore blockage, although undetected catalyst losses during the washing steps cannot be ruled out. The aforementioned results show the benefit of impregnating MgO sites into CTFs. As for Entry 1, around 0.6 mol% of active catalyst was enough to give the optimal product conversions. It is worth noting that the method excludes the need for additional solvent. Compared to previously reported heterogenous systems for converting aliphatic aldehydes into α–β unsaturated products (Table S7), the high product conversion at a low catalyst/reagent ratio of the proposed approach should be emphasized. Additionally, the method excludes the need for an inert gas atmosphere, solvents, or high-pressure reactors, requiring only common glassware. 2.3 Propanolysis of 4-nitrophenyl acetate (4-NPA) The activity of the MgO@CTFs were also evaluated in the transesterification reaction between 4-nitrophenyl acetate (4-NPA) and n-propanol ( Scheme 2). 4-NPA is a model compound typically used to verify the catalytic activity of basic catalysts and lipases [75,76]. One of the products in these processes is 4-nitrophenol, which strongly absorbs at 400 nm upon deprotonation, allowing the reaction to be conveniently monitored by UV-Vis. Hence, 5MgAc@CTF was select among the materials to verify catalytic activity. The kinetic profiles of Fig. 5 clearly show the increment in the reaction rate upon addition of the catalyst. By a pseudo first-order nonlinear fit of the data, a rate improvement of 1.6 and 4.5-fold factor is observed when 17 and 51 µmol of substrate per gram of catalyst are employed, respectively. The better activity of MgO@CTF is evident when the kinetic profile is compared to that of pure CTF. It is also interesting to point that 5MgAc@CTF is as active as pure MgO. On a mol basis, this confirms that MgO dispersed on CTF is more reactive than bulky MgO, displaying a 21-fold increase in TOF. 2.4 Propanolysis of paraoxon-ethyl Building on the successful performance of 5MgAc@CTF in the model ester propanolysis, its catalytic activity was further evaluated in a more challenging and intriguing system: paraoxon-ethyl propanolysis. Organophosphates are widely utilized in various applications, despite their high toxicity to humans. Given the significant number of human intoxication cases caused by this class of compounds, extensive efforts have been dedicated their degradation into less harmful derivatives [77]. The prolonged stability of some of these compounds in aqueous systems has driven researchers to develop more effective degradation strategies. Paraoxon-ethyl, for instance, is a highly toxic pesticide with a hydrolysis half-life of approximately 80 days at pH 7 and room temperature [78]. Through the propanolysis reaction of this compound ( Scheme 3), a trialkyl phosphate is produced, which is considerably less toxic and structurally analogous to flame retardants compounds [79]. Previous studies have demonstrated that magnesium, aluminum, erbium and strontium oxides are highly effective in catalyzing the propanolysis of paraoxon-methyl [80–82]. Remarkably, even commercial MgO can enhance the reaction rate by approximately 106-fold compared to the spontaneous propanolysis of paraoxon-methyl [83]. Computational calculations suggest that the high catalytic efficiency of the reaction arises from the interaction between adsorbed propanol and organophosphate molecules on the solid surface. In this environment, nucleophilic and electrophilic centers are positioned at adjacent Mg2+ sites, maintaining an intermolecular separation of approximately 2.4 Å [83]. Therefore, we evaluated the catalytic activity of MgO@CTFs materials in the propanolysis of paraoxon-ethyl. Kinetics studies of the propanolysis evidenced significant gains achieved with the impregnation of MgO into the CTF structure ( Fig. 6). In these experiments, the amounts of propanol and paraxon-ethyl were kept constant, while the amount and nature of catalyst were varied. Approximately 30 mg of 5MgAc@CTF was necessary to achieve over 90 % conversion after 48 h of reaction, whereas negligible conversion was observed when the same amount of pure CTF was used (∼ 5 %). Compared to pure CTF, the initial reaction rate increased approximately 25-fold with 10 mg of 5MgAc@CTF and 60-fold with 30 mg of the same material. The catalytic performance becomes more noticeable when compared to the spontaneous reaction, exhibiting a nearly 300-fold enhancement in the initial rate (Figure S37). Although the CTF support itself displayed only weak basicity, as determined by CO2-TPD, it still produced a slight improvement in reaction rate. However, it is clear that the remarkable catalytic activity of 5MgAc@CTF stems from the presence of impregnated MgO sites. To further confirm the presence of the propanolysis product, GC-MS analysis of the reaction medium catalyzed by 5MgAc@CTF was performed. Diethyl propyl phosphate was identified in the chromatogram with a retention time of 5.84 min, as confirmed by the corresponding mass spectra (Figure S38-39). Moreover, no residual paraoxon (r.t. of 15.48 min) was detected, supporting the spectrophotometric evidence of its complete conversion to the phosphate triester product. Additionally, a kinetic experiment on the propanolysis of paraoxon was performed using the same mass of commercial MgO (Fig. 6B). Despite having a metal oxide content approximately 21 times higher on a molar basis, the pure MgO exhibited lower catalytic activity compared to 5MgAc@CTF. This difference may be correlated with the basicity profiles revealed by CO2-TPD measurements for both materials. Assuming roughly that CO2 chemisorption in MgO@CTF originates exclusively from the impregnated basic sites, the amount of CO2 desorbed per mass of active base was approximately 26 times greater for 5MgAc@CTF, highlighting the effect of the support on inducing accessibility to the basic sites. For the sake of comparison, the catalytic performance of MgO deposited on Al2O3 was also probed. As shown in Figure S40, 5MgAc@Al2O3 exhibited significantly lower activity, underscoring the superior role of CTF as a support of MgO active sites for basic catalysis. In order to better understand the specific role of the CTF as a support, some computational studies were performed. DFT modeling was employed to investigate the interactions between CTFs and propanol and paraoxon-ethyl. Fully relaxed geometries for all systems examined in this study are shown in Figure 7 and S41, providing spatial representations of how individual propanol and paraoxon-ethyl molecules interact with the CTF structure. Due to the relatively large molecular volume of paraoxon-ethyl, two distinct adsorption scenarios were considered: i) adsorption on the external surface of the CTF (Figures S41C and S41D), and ii) adsorption within the internal pore environment ( Figs. 7C and 7D). This comparison is essential for the subsequent analysis of the adsorption energies of these two models. The adsorption models offer valuable insights into both the magnitude and nature of interactions between the CTF surface and the target molecules. Computational results reveal that propanol adsorption on the CTF surface (Fig. 7A) is thermodynamically favorable, with an adsorption energy of - 70.84 kJ·mol−1. The absence of specific bonding interactions suggests that the adsorption is primarily governed by Van der Waals forces. Paraoxon-ethyl exhibits a markedly stronger interaction when confined within the CTF pores, with an adsorption energy of - 141.34 kJ·mol−1 (Fig. 7C), compared to a significantly weaker interaction on the external surface (Eads = 47.73 kJ·mol−1, Figure S41D). Within the pore environment, specific interactions are observed between hydrogen atoms of the CTF and oxygen atoms from the nitro and P = O groups of paraoxon-ethyl, with interatomic distances ranging from 2.20 to 2.32 Å. The favorable interactions between the reagents and the CTF are further supported by density of states (DOS) analysis. As shown in Figure S42, all investigated systems exhibit a high density of energy levels near the Fermi level, along with minimal changes in the band gap compared to the isolated CTF surface (Figure S42A). As previously reported in the literature, this behavior demonstrates a favorable surface adsorption [84–86]. However, in the case of paraoxon-ethyl approaching the CTF surface, the DOS reveals a low concentration of energy states in the conduction band, suggesting weak or negligible electronic interaction. This observation aligns with the adsorption energy data, reinforcing the conclusion that paraoxon-ethyl interacts preferentially within the CTF pores rather than on the external surface. The enhanced catalytic activity of MgO@CTF compared to pure MgO may stem from favorable interactions between the reactants and the porous structure of the CTF. It is plausible that propoxide intermediates are generated within the confined environment of the CTF pores by the confined MgO particles. These reactive species could then migrate toward the pore entrances, where they encounter and react with adsorbed paraoxon molecules. This spatial proximity and confinement likely facilitate more efficient catalytic turnover by promoting reactive species encounter. Thus, CTF proves to be an effective support for MgO incorporation in catalytic applications. Characterization data indicate that MgO is well-dispersed within the porous framework, leading to a marked increase in basicity, despite the expected reduction in surface area and pore volume. This uniform distribution, accompanied with improved accessibility of basic sites, contributes to the notably higher molar catalytic activity observed in the paraoxon degradation reaction. 3 Conclusion In this work, we successfully impregnated MgO into CTFs. Until now, the incorporation of basic sites into this class of materials has primarily been explored through the formation of alkali oxides, which are chemically unstable. The proposed method for MgO@CTFs preparation preserves both crystallinity and chemical structure of the support. An impregnation level of approximately 5 wt% MgO was found to be optimal for both salts explored in the impregnation step. At this level a significant increase in basicity, as confirmed by CO2-TPD analysis, was achieved without substantially affecting the porosity, ensuring high dispersibility of the metal oxide at the support, as implied by XRPD results and HAADF-STEM-EDX images. Catalytic studies demonstrated that MgO@CTFs function as active catalysts across distinct chemical reactions. The materials promoted the production of an α–β unsaturated aldehyde at elevated temperatures in the absence of additional solvent, with optimal performance observed at 5 wt% metal oxide impregnated material. Furthermore, the system was evaluated to certify the catalytic reusability of the material, showing no substantial loss in the activity and requiring no additional activation steps. The material was further evaluated in the propanolysis reaction of both an ester and an organophosphate. In both cases, MgO impregnation notably enhanced the reaction rate, particularly in the challenging cleavage of paraoxon-ethyl, where the conversion increased remarkably from 5 % to 92 % within 48 h. DFT studies revealed favorable interactions between propanol and paraoxon-ethyl with the CTF framework, offering mechanistic insights into the degradation pathway of the organophosphate. The superior catalytic performance of 5MgAc@CTF compared to equivalent amounts of commercial MgO highlights the advantages of incorporating the metal oxide into the support. Our findings open new possibilities for utilizing CTFs in catalysis and further applications. Since their discovery, CTFs have been widely explored in diverse catalytic categories (photocatalysis, electrocatalysis, organocatalysis, etc…) and other relevant applications, whether being post-functionalized or not. The potential synergic effects of the strong and chemical stable basic sites incorporated in the CTFs, combined with their many outstanding physical properties and chemical functionalities, pave the way for vast innovative research directions. coredata.dc:description: Covalent triazine frameworks (CTFs) have emerged as robust materials with high thermal and chemical stability, tunable porosity, and significant potential for sustainable applications in catalysis, adsorption, and gas storage and separation. Recent advances have focused on enhancing their intrinsic basicity through the incorporation of alkali oxides, which, although effective, exhibit limited moisture stability. For many practical applications, developing strongly basic, water-tolerant CTFs remains a critical challenge. In this work, magnesium oxide-impregnated covalent triazine frameworks (MgO@CTFs) were successfully synthesized through a sequential process involving the wet impregnation of magnesium salts onto CTFs, followed by thermal decomposition. The synthesis procedure was optimized by investigating the best ratio of the metal salt precursor to support, as well as the type of metal precursor. Impregnation of MgO at 5 wt% provided the best compromise between enhanced basicity and retention of porosity. The materials were thoroughly characterized to confirm their structure, composition, and porosity. Their catalytic performance was evaluated in the production of 2-hexyl-2-decenal from octanal, achieving over 80 % conversion at 170 °C within 4 h, as well as in the propanolysis of 4-nitrophenylacetate (4-NPA) and paraoxon-ethyl. Remarkably, reaction rates improved by factors of 4.5 (4-NPA) and 300 (paraxon) compared to the respective spontaneous reaction. DTF studies indicate that the CTF framework interacts with propanol and paraoxon-ethyl, facilitating the interaction between the reactive species. This study presents an effective strategy to introduce stable basic sites into CTFs without compromising their porosity or stability, expanding their applicability in base-catalyzed reactions and other advanced applications.
